questions.question_text:
You use the Two-Class Neural Network module in Azure Machine Learning Studio to build a binary classification model. You use the Tune Model
Hyperparameters module to tune accuracy for the model.
You need to configure the Tune Model Hyperparameters module.
Which two values should you use? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: The correct answer is B and D.

comments.content:
Agree. ACE are structure related parameters which are not changed during the training process, but B and D are parameters that govern the training process. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/how-to-tune-hyperparameters

I think D and E - See below
https://towardsdatascience.com/what-are-hyperparameters-and-how-to-tune-the-hyperparameters-in-a-deep-neural-network-d0604917584a

discussion.content:
The idea here is that, ABC are hyperparameters that Azure can figure out for you, but it needs D and E.
why D? Because Azure needs to know when to stop. I.e. it can't run forever
why E? Because you need to tell Azure what to "sweep over". Is it to sweep over hidden layer breadth? Depth? both? for each of these sweep runs, it tries a permutation of learning rate and kernel function etc

Selected Answer: BD
The correct answer is B and D.

BDE
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/component-reference/two-class-neural-network?view=azureml-api-2

A. Number of hidden nodes
B. Learning Rate

A. Number of hidden nodes
B. Learning Rate

Selected Answer: BD
B and D

A. Number of hidden nodes
B. Learning Rate

When configuring the Tune Model Hyperparameters module to tune accuracy for a Two-Class Neural Network model in Azure Machine Learning Studio, you should select the hyperparameters you want to tune. In this case, you should select the number of hidden nodes and the learning rate. These are two of the most important hyperparameters for a neural network and can significantly impact the accuracy of the model. The other options listed (C, D, and E) are not relevant hyperparameters for the Two-Class Neural Network module. The type of normalizer is a preprocessing step and is not a hyperparameter for the model. The number of learning iterations and the hidden layer specification are both set by the Two-Class Neural Network module and cannot be directly tuned using the Tune Model Hyperparameters module.

Selected Answer: BD
Learning rate and hidden layer specification. No idea why (ironically) the community vote is tied at 50-50 on question about binary classification :)

Selected Answer: DE
As per Parimt's explanation

Other options are not in properties of Tune Model Hyperparameters .

the answer is 'B' and 'D'
if 'D' and 'E' are correct then 'A' i also has to be correct.

B and D: The 2-class Neural Network has only 2 parameters that can be set to "range" (instead of "single parameter"), which in turn can be learned by the Tune Model Hyperparameters module: 1) number of iterations 2) Learning rate.

B and D

Below some text from the "Two-Class Neural Network module":

4. For "Learning rate", define the size of the step taken at each iteration, before correction. A larger value for
learning rate can cause the model to converge faster, but it can overshoot local minima.
5. For "Number of learning iterations", specify the maximum number of times the algorithm should process
the training cases.

comments.content: I agree... you explained the exact point of the question!

discussion.content: I think is B and D

Lookng at the Two-Class Neural Network module, the only two values that allow you to use the Range Builder after set "Parameter Range" for Create Trainer Mode option (so they are used by the Tune Model Hyperparameters module) are:
 - Learning Rate
 - Number of iterations

So the right answer is: BD
aren't all these are hyperparameters?

A and D

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are running a training experiment on remote compute in Azure Machine Learning.
The experiment is configured to use a conda environment that includes the mlflow and azureml-contrib-run packages.
You must use MLflow as the logging package for tracking metrics generated in the experiment.
You need to complete the script for the experiment.
How should you complete the code? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: import mlflow -
Import the mlflow and Workspace classes to access MLflow's tracking URI and configure your workspace.
Box 2: mlflow.start_run()
Set the MLflow experiment name with set_experiment() and start your training run with start_run().
Box 3: mlflow.log_metric(' ..')
Use log_metric() to activate the MLflow logging API and begin logging your training run metrics.
Box 4: mlflow.end_run()
Close the run:
run.endRun()
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/how-to-use-mlflow

discussion.content:
Random grid:
You can also reduce the size of the grid and run a random grid sweep. Research has shown that this method yields the same results, but is more efficient computationally.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/studio-module-reference/tune-model-hyperparameters

D is right. 
A is incorrect, as Random Sweep does not iterate all possible combination and randomly select parameters
B is incorrect, as it is only for clustering algos
C is incorrect, as Entire grid is resource intensive

The question's requirements seem a bit contradictory as it asks to "iterate all possible combinations of hyperparameters" (which points to Entire Grid) but also to "minimize computing resources required to perform the sweep" (which points to Random Sweep/Grid).

If we prioritize iterating over all combinations, then Entire Grid would be chosen. However, if we prioritize minimizing computational resources, then Random Sweep/Grid would be more suitable. As the question initially asks for iterating over all combinations, I chose Entire Grid in my previous response, but I acknowledge that if resource usage is a primary concern, Random Sweep/Grid would be more appropriate.

comments.content: I agree with you. To meet the requirement of iterating all possible combinations of hyperparameters while minimizing computing resources, you should use the “Entire grid” parameter sweep mode in Azure Machine Learning Studio. This mode performs a grid search over the entire hyperparameter space, trying all possible combinations of hyperparameter values. While this can be computationally expensive, it ensures that all combinations are tried and can result in finding the best combination of hyperparameters for your model. To minimize computing resources, you can carefully choose the range and granularity of the hyperparameters to be swept, and use parallel processing to speed up the sweep

discussion.content:
C. To iterate all possible combinations of hyperparameters, you should use the "Entire grid" parameter sweep mode in Azure Machine Learning Studio. This mode will sweep over all possible combinations of the hyperparameters that you specify.

While the "Random sweep" and "Random grid" modes can also help you minimize computing resources by only evaluating a subset of possible combinations, they may not guarantee that you will evaluate all possible combinations of hyperparameters. On the other hand, the "Sweep clustering" mode is not a valid parameter sweep mode in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

comments.content: The question is asking for check all possible combinations, not asking for the best results ...

comments.content: Cannot be random grid as the only options in tune hyperparameters module are either entire grid or random sweep. Entire grid is compute intensive, which leaves only random sweep.
Only Entire Grid and Randow Sweep options are available. I would go with Random sweep since the question specifies that it should be computationally inexpensive.
Agree. There are only TWO options that can be selected, Entire Grid and Random Sweep.

discussion.content: its tricky, you could specify exit criteria in entire grid to gain performance but its not given in the option so random grid is answer.

I earlier thought, it should be Entire gird, but, there is another requirement of using optimized compute resources, for this, Random Sweep is the best method, with max number of iteration=size of entire grid.

Random sweep: When you select this option, the module will randomly select parameter values over a system-defined range. You must specify the maximum number of runs that you want the module to execute. This option is useful for cases where you want to increase model performance using the metrics of your choice but still conserve computing resources.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/studio-module-reference/tune-model-hyperparameters

There are only two possible options, if you look at the documentation: 1) Entire grid and 2) Random sweep. There is no such thing as random grid or entire sweep. Correct answer is Random sweep as it's more efficient.

The only 2 available options inside the "Tune Model Hyperparameters" module are: 
- Random sweep
- Entire grid

Since we have to be efficient computationally, I would select A, "Random sweep".
I don't see that a "Random grid" option exists inside the module. Therefore, how can it be the correct answer to this question?

I think the answer is C. Entire grid
The question says the search should try all possible combinations, which is what entire grid does. Random grid does not guarantee that all combinations are tested?

comments.content: But the second requirement asks to minimize compute resources. Even grid will attempt every single combination and that will be the worst case scenario in terms of compute resources. Random Grid will iterate through all possible combinations and only execute a subset of these combinations. That's why it makes most sense for this questions.
You can also reduce the size of the grid and run a random grid sweep. Research has shown that this method yields the same results, but is more efficient computationally.

questions.answer_description:
Maximum number of runs on random grid: This option also controls the number of iterations over a random sampling of parameter values, but the values are not generated randomly from the specified range; instead, a matrix is created of all possible combinations of parameter values and a random sampling is taken over the matrix. This method is more efficient and less prone to regional oversampling or undersampling.
If you are training a model that supports an integrated parameter sweep, you can also set a range of seed values to use and iterate over the random seeds as well. This is optional, but can be useful for avoiding bias introduced by seed selection.
Incorrect Answers:
B: If you are building a clustering model, use Sweep Clustering to automatically determine the optimum number of clusters and other parameters.
C: Entire grid: When you select this option, the module loops over a grid predefined by the system, to try different combinations and identify the best learner. This option is useful for cases where you don't know what the best parameter settings might be and want to try all possible combination of values.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/studio-module-reference/tune-model-hyperparameters
questions.question_text:
You create a binary classification model by using Azure Machine Learning Studio.
You must tune hyperparameters by performing a parameter sweep of the model. The parameter sweep must meet the following requirements:
✑ iterate all possible combinations of hyperparameters
✑ minimize computing resources required to perform the sweep
You need to perform a parameter sweep of the model.
Which parameter sweep mode should you use?

discussion.content:
Def of Overfit:
Train Accuracy is High (aka Less Loss), Test Accuracy is Low (aka High Loss)
Going by this, answer B is correct to me
This answer is correct guys

B is correct

Selected Answer: B

discussion.content:
The mentioned answer is wrong.
The correct answer is
graph-1--> negatively skewed
Graph-2-> positively skewed
reference: https://www.statisticshowto.com/probability-and-statistics/skewed-distribution/

choices.B: The training loss decreases while the validation loss increases when training the model.
choices.C: The training loss stays constant and the validation loss decreases when training the model.
choices.A: The training loss stays constant and the validation loss stays on a constant value and close to the training loss value when training the model.
choices.D: The training loss increases while the validation loss decreases when training the model.

questions.question_text:
You are building a recurrent neural network to perform a binary classification.
You review the training loss, validation loss, training accuracy, and validation accuracy for each training epoch.
You need to analyze model performance.
You need to identify whether the classification model is overfitted.
Which of the following is correct?

discussion.content: Question was there in June 2021 Exam
Exactly this question was on exam 07/March/2023

Selected Answer: B
Remote VMs are considered as a unmanaged and can require extra steps for you to maintain or to improve performance for machine learning workloads. I interpret this as you won't be able to log the metrics out-of-the box. Link: require extra steps for you to maintain or to improve performance for machine learning workloads. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/concept-compute-target?view=azureml-api-2#unmanaged-compute

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
An IT department creates the following Azure resource groups and resources:
//IMG//

The IT department creates an Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)-based inference compute target named aks-cluster in the Azure Machine Learning workspace.
You have a Microsoft Surface Book computer with a GPU. Python 3.6 and Visual Studio Code are installed.
You need to run a script that trains a deep neural network (DNN) model and logs the loss and accuracy metrics.
Solution: Attach the mlvm virtual machine as a compute target in the Azure Machine Learning workspace. Install the Azure ML SDK on the Surface Book and run
Python code to connect to the workspace. Run the training script as an experiment on the mlvm remote compute resource.
Does the solution meet the goal?
